Package org.naomi.regex

Provides the power of regular expressions without regular expressions.

See: Description

  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    AlterationListener
    The listener interface for receiving notifications of changes in an instance of Pattern that might affect which Strings it matches.
    BuiltInInterface
    This Interface applies to all of the BuiltIn Enums listed below, each of which defines a set of constant values that specify a different pre-defined set of characters to be matched.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    BackReferencePattern
    An instance of this Pattern matches the same string matched by some previously matched Pattern (specified by the referent argument of the BackReferencePattern Constructor).
    BoundaryPattern
    An instance of BoundaryPattern matches, on each repetition, the left or right boundary (as specified) of some string, e.g., the start or end of a line, word or non-word.
    BuiltInCharClass
    An instance of BuiltInCharClass is a Pattern which, on each repetition, matches any single character in the pre-defined set of characters denoted by its instantiating BuiltIn Enum constant.
    CharClass
    An instance of any subclass of this abstract class is a Pattern which, on each repetition, matches any single character in the set of characters that define that instance.
    CharSequencePattern
    An instance of CharSequencePattern matches, on each repetition, the entire character sequence in the String or other CharSequence (e.g., CharBuffer or Segment of a character array) used to instantiate the CharSequencePattern.
    CollectionCharClass
    An instance of CollectionCharClass is a Pattern which, on each repetition, matches any single character in the Collection of Characters used to instantiate the CollectionCharClass.
    ComplementCharClass  
    ConcatenatePattern
    A ConcatenatePattern matches the concatenation of strings matched by the specified instances of Pattern.
    DelegateCharClass  
    EnumPattern
    An instance of EnumPattern matches, on each repetition, any of the strings corresponding to the constants of the Enum used to instantiate the EnumPattern.
    ExplicitCharClass
    An instance of ExplicitCharClass is a Pattern which, on each repetition, matches any single character in the String or other CharSequence used to the instantiate the ExplicitCharClass.
    FilterCharClass
    An instance of FilterCharClass is a Pattern which, on each repetition, matches any single character that lies inclusively (in the normal collating sequence) between FilterCharClass.getFirst() and FilterCharClass.getLast() and satisfies filter(Char).
    GlobPattern
    A GlobPattern is a Pattern that behaves like a Unix shell filename matching pattern.
    IntersectCharClass
    An instance of IntersectCharClass is a Pattern which, on each repetition, matches any single character that is in all of the CharClasses in the instantiating Collection or list of CharClasses.
    IntervalCharClass
    An instance of IntervalCharClass is a Pattern which, on each repetition, matches any single character that lies inclusively (in the normal collating sequence) between two specified characters.
    Matcher
    This class (which is analogous to but distinct from java.util.regex.Matcher) is the Naomi package's engine that performs match operations on a character sequence by interpreting a Pattern.
    OrPattern
    An OrPattern matches any string matched by at least one of the specified instances of Pattern.
    Pattern
    A Pattern, matches certain strings, that is, it is a filter on strings.
    Pretty
    This class governs the display of regular expressions (see getRegularExpression and setPretty), to generate expressions which are more human readable—or, more precisely, less unreadable.
    RegExpPattern
    A RegExpPattern matches the strings matched by a given regular expression.
    UnionCharClass
    An instance of UnionCharClass is a Pattern which, on each repetition, matches any single character that is in any of the CharClasses in its instantiating Collection or list of CharClasses.
    Utilities  
  • Enum Summary 
    Enum Description
    Action
    The constants defined by this Enum specify what action to take when more than one match is found by one of the Utilities.find methods.
    Boundary
    Each constant defined by this Enum specifies a boundary (word, line, etc.) that is to be matched by an instance of BoundaryPattern instantiated with this value.
    CoreBuiltIn
    This Enum defines a set of constants, each of which specifies a pre-defined "Core" set of characters to be matched (as described below).
    LocaleBuiltIn
    This Enum defines a set of constants, each of which specifies a pre-defined "Locale" set of characters to be matched (as described below).
    Policy
    This Enum provides constant values for the setPolicy(Policy policy) method of Pattern and its subclasses, which controls various behavior and performance aspects of matching for a given pattern.
    Side
    The constants defined by this enum are left and right.
    UniBlockBuiltIn
    This Enum defines a set of constants, each of which specifies a Unicode "block" of characters to be matched (see below).
    UniScriptBuiltIn
    This Enum defines a set of constants, each of which specifies a Unicode "script" of characters to be matched (see below).
    Verbose
    The constants defined by this enum are no, yes and very.
  • Exception Summary 
    Exception Description
    BackReferencePattern.BackReferenceException
    Thrown when a BackReferencePattern has an inappropriate referent.
    BadCountException
    Thrown when the Policy of a Pattern is incompatible with the Pattern's min or max count.
    Bug
    Thrown to indicate that an internal bug within Naomi has been encountered.
    IntervalCharClass.BadIntervalException
    Thrown when the character values right < left (in the normal collating sequence).
    Pretty.BadPrettyException
    Thrown when an instance of Pretty has a bad field
    ReuseException
    Thrown to indicate that an attempt has been made by one Pattern to use another Pattern more than once.
    UnusedException
    Thrown to indicate that information about some Pattern was solicited in the context of a Pattern that did not use that Pattern.
    Utilities.SearchException
    Thrown when no or more than one Object is inappropriately found

Package org.naomi.regex Description

Provides the power of regular expressions without regular expressions.
Some people, when confronted with a problem, think, "I know, I'll use regular expressions." Now they have two problems.
- Jaimie Zawinski

Naomi is a package that enables Java programmers to search for and optionally replace textual patterns in documents or strings. Simple tasks of this sort--such as systematically changing multiple filenames or modifying text in documents--are often performed using inline or one-shot scripts written using tools such as awk, sed, or Perl, all of which use (somewhat different) variants of regular expression ("RE") syntax. The standard java.util.regex package provides its own set of RE tools for use in Java. But performing complex searching and match-and-replace tasks or performing such tasks repetitively with minor variations can be quite difficult using REs, and RE syntax is inherently alien to Java's object-oriented style of programming. Naomi offers a much more transparent way of attacking such problems that is more compatible with Java style and much better suited to larger problems.

That is, Naomi provides the power of regular expressions without regular expressions.

Although regular expressions offer a quick and terse way to perform simple matching and replacement operations, they are infuriatingly difficult to scale up to more complex problems. Their terseness, arcane notation, reliance on the heavy use of escape characters, and lack of modularity and encapsulation make them difficult to write, read, understand, maintain, modify, reuse, and extend, for all but the simplest of problems. Naomi's approach, though considerably less terse, offers far greater clarity, modularity, reusability, and extensibility. Naomi is not intended as a replacement for regular expressions in simple cases but rather as an alternative for tackling more complex problems and for producing more transparent solutions.

Even pattern matching problems that start out seeming to be simple have a way of turning out to be more complex than they first appeared--either because they evolve to cover additional cases or because we realize that our original solution was insufficiently general. Naomi can therefore be a better approach even for simple problems, since they often turn into complex ones.

Naomi provides two main classes, Pattern and Matcher, which are analogous to the corresponding classes in the java.util.regex package. These Naomi classes, along with the subclasses of its Pattern class and some other ancillary classes, provide a way to match patterns in strings without using regular expressions.

Java programmers who are familiar with the use of regular expressions should have little trouble grasping the Naomi paradigm and reaping its advantages for complex pattern matching and replacement. Those who have not been exposed to REs should find Naomi a kinder, gentler approach to dealing with textual pattern matching and replacement, in a way that scales well to large problems.

Bridges to and from regular expressions:
Naomi shields the user from having to deal with regular expressions. However, for legacy applications, the class RegExpPattern provides a bridge from regular expressions, and the method Pattern.getRegularExpression() provides a bridge to regular expressions.
Chaining:
Almost all of the methods of Naomi that do not otherwise return something useful return the object on which they were invoked.
Version:
2015-03-09_17:55
Author:
Norman Shapiro, Jeff Rothenberg
